results.headline: A Bad Day at the Office
results.summary_short: Swift and stealthy “P2” is a canny exploitation of one of the urban woman’s greatest fears: the after-hours parking garage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of P2

results.headline: Hearts and Minds: Senator Meets Reporter, Selling a New, Improved War
results.summary_short: Career Politicians, the Fourth Estate and Disaffected Youth all earn a stern knuckle rapping in “Lions for Lambs.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lions for Lambs

results.headline: Righting Human Wrongs
results.summary_short: There’s a riveting story lurking inside “Holly.” It’s just not the one the filmmakers want to tell.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Holly

results.headline: The Dependent Claus
results.summary_short: “Fred Claus” is a tacky would-be comedy about family dysfunction that fronts some Scrooge attitude only to dissolve into slobbering sentimentality and canned uplift.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fred Claus

results.headline: A Scrappy Tale of a Presidential Campaign
results.summary_short: “Cocalero,” Alejandro Landes’s documentary about the presidential campaign of Evo Morales in Bolivia, seems to mirror the campaign itself: ragged and bare-bones.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cocalero

results.headline: Damaged Perceptions
results.summary_short: “Choking Man” is harsh and intermittently affecting but oppressively contrived and mostly pointless.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Choking Man

results.headline: Free-Jazz Pioneer, Aware of His Legacy
results.summary_short: The Ohio-born tenor saxophonist Albert Ayler probably would have gotten a kick out of Kasper Collin’s documentary about his life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name Is Albert Ayler

results.headline: What’s Black and White and Made in Queens?
results.summary_short: “Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037” follows the painstaking yearlong process of building and fine-tuning a handmade nine-foot concert grand piano.
results.display_title: Note By Note: The Making of Steinway L1037

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Note By Note: The Making of Steinway L1037

results.headline: Telling a Tale of Torment, Wordlessly
results.summary_short: The pungent layers of narrative that make up “Glass Lips” may cross and collide — and occasionally confuse — but the intelligence behind them is clear.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glass Lips

results.headline: Friends Sitting Around a Campfire, Telling Stories About a Legend
results.summary_short: “The Future is Unwritten” is much more than a biography of the Clash’s guitarist and lead singer: It’s history, philosophy and politics, played fast and loud.
results.display_title: Joe Strummer:  The Future is Unwritten

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joe Strummer:  The Future is Unwritten

results.headline: Cut the Scary Music: Here Sharks Are More Endangered Than Dangerous
results.summary_short: The ocean is just large enough to contain the ambition of “Sharkwater.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sharkwater

results.headline: Man Meets Boy, Surrenders Heart
results.summary_short: There’s nothing wrong with the setup of “Martian Child,” but there’s little right about the delivery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Martian Child

results.headline: Struggling Against Circumstance
results.summary_short: “Love and Honor,” the final episode in Yoji Yamada’s samurai trilogy, maintains the grace and resonance of its predecessors as well as their focus on class inequality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love and Honor

results.headline: Sweet, Bloody Smell of Success
results.summary_short: Greatness hovers just outside “American Gangster,” knocking, angling to be let in.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Gangster

results.headline: Broad Comedy
results.summary_short: “Fat Girls” doesn’t know what it wants to be and ends up stranded between two concepts, either of which might have yielded a more satisfying film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fat Girls

results.headline: Darfur’s Many Horrors, and Glimmers of Hope
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Darfur Now,” progress inches along on several fronts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darfur Now

results.headline: Of Birds and Planes
results.summary_short: Superman doesn’t solicit donations, but he accepts tips in “Confessions of a Superhero.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confessions of a Superhero

results.headline: A Drone No More: No Hive for Him!
results.summary_short: The most genuinely apian aspect of “Bee Movie” is that it spends a lot of its running time buzzing happily around, sniffing out fresh jokes wherever they may bloom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bee Movie

results.headline: Dismemberment Entree, Heaping Side of Screams
results.summary_short: “Saw IV” is bloody proof that Jigsaw may be dead, but his well of corporeal abuses has yet to run dry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw IV

results.headline: A Man, His Movies and, Sometimes, His Monkey
results.summary_short: Whether you dig “Lynch,” a feature-length video visit with the director David Lynch, will largely depend on your views of his work.
